# The `PassBuilder` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

## Description {#details}

This class provides access to building LLVM&#39;s passes.

Its members provide the baseline state available to passes during their construction. The <code>PassRegistry.def</code> file specifies how to construct all of the built-in passes, and those may reference these members during construction.

Definition at line 105 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>.

### buildFunctionSimplificationPipeline() {#a9501d22da3319c387a0a617fc4ffcc31}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>FunctionPassManager PassBuilder::buildFunctionSimplificationPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/optimizationlevel">OptimizationLevel</a> Level, <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a5d737fb4258bb27586a1bffd557fbb49">ThinOrFullLTOPhase</a> Phase)</>}>
Construct the core LLVM function canonicalization and simplification pipeline.

This is a long pipeline and uses most of the per-function optimization passes in LLVM to canonicalize and simplify the IR. It is suitable to run repeatedly over the IR and is not expected to destroy important information about the semantics of the IR.

Note that <code>Level</code> cannot be <code>O0</code> here. The pipelines produced are only intended for use when attempting to optimize code. If frontends require some transformations for semantic reasons, they should explicitly build them.

<code>Phase</code> indicates the current ThinLTO phase.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00194">194</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp/#l00549">549</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp">PassBuilderPipelines.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<MemberDefinition

Build a pre-link, LTO-targeting default optimization pipeline to a pass manager.

This adds the pre-link optimizations tuned to work well with a later LTO run. It works to minimize the IR which needs to be analyzed without making irreversible decisions which could be made better during the LTO run.

### buildModuleOptimizationPipeline() {#adf20f88f2a71fd5cd08708b9da72979a}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>ModulePassManager PassBuilder::buildModuleOptimizationPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/optimizationlevel">OptimizationLevel</a> Level, <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a5d737fb4258bb27586a1bffd557fbb49">ThinOrFullLTOPhase</a> LTOPhase)</>}>
Construct the core LLVM module optimization pipeline.

This pipeline focuses on optimizing the execution speed of the IR. It uses cost modeling and thresholds to balance code growth against runtime improvements. It includes vectorization and other information destroying transformations. It also cannot generally be run repeatedly on a module without potentially seriously regressing either runtime performance of the code or serious code size growth.

Note that <code>Level</code> cannot be <code>O0</code> here. The pipelines produced are only intended for use when attempting to optimize code. If frontends require some transformations for semantic reasons, they should explicitly build them.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00239">239</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp/#l01414">1414</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp">PassBuilderPipelines.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### buildModuleSimplificationPipeline() {#ad6f258d31ffa2d2e4dfaf990ba596d0d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>ModulePassManager PassBuilder::buildModuleSimplificationPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/optimizationlevel">OptimizationLevel</a> Level, <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a5d737fb4258bb27586a1bffd557fbb49">ThinOrFullLTOPhase</a> Phase)</>}>
Construct the core LLVM module canonicalization and simplification pipeline.

This pipeline focuses on canonicalizing and simplifying the entire module of IR. Much like the function simplification pipeline above, it is suitable to run repeatedly over the IR and is not expected to destroy important information. It does, however, perform inlining and other heuristic based simplifications that are not strictly reversible.

Note that <code>Level</code> cannot be <code>O0</code> here. The pipelines produced are only intended for use when attempting to optimize code. If frontends require some transformations for semantic reasons, they should explicitly build them.

<code>Phase</code> indicates the current ThinLTO phase.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00212">212</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp/#l01048">1048</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilderpipelines-cpp">PassBuilderPipelines.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### parseAAPipeline() {#a1d4e2a477b2b896adfdec5e55638b725}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Error PassBuilder::parseAAPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/aamanager">AAManager</a> &amp; AA, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> PipelineText)</>}>
Parse a textual alias analysis pipeline into the provided <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a> manager.

The format of the textual <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a> pipeline is a comma separated list of <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a> pass names:

basic-aa,globals-aa,...

The <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a> manager is set up such that the provided alias analyses are tried in the order specified. See the <code>AAManaager</code> documentation for details about the logic used. This routine just provides the textual mapping between <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a> names and the analyses to register with the manager.

Returns false if the text cannot be parsed cleanly. The specific state of the <code><a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/aa">AA</a></code> manager is unspecified if such an error is encountered and this returns false.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00392">392</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilder-cpp/#l02371">2371</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilder-cpp">PassBuilder.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### parsePassPipeline() {#a9ca0e57e6445ab2fe568e53ba29cc0fd}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Error PassBuilder::parsePassPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a79ab9199d2ba6a1c9cac2b79efc194a3">ModulePassManager</a> &amp; MPM, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> PipelineText)</>}>
Parse a textual pass pipeline description into a <code><a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a79ab9199d2ba6a1c9cac2b79efc194a3">ModulePassManager</a></code>.

The format of the textual pass pipeline description looks something like:

module(function(instcombine,sroa),dce,cgscc(inliner,function(...)),...)

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pass">Pass</a> managers have ()s describing the nest structure of passes. All passes are comma separated. As a special shortcut, if the very first pass is not a module pass (as a module pass manager is), this will automatically form the shortest stack of pass managers that allow inserting that first pass. So, assuming function passes &#39;fpassN&#39;, CGSCC passes &#39;cgpassN&#39;, and loop passes &#39;lpassN&#39;, all of these are valid:

fpass1,fpass2,fpass3 cgpass1,cgpass2,cgpass3 lpass1,lpass2,lpass3

And they are equivalent to the following (resp.):

module(function(fpass1,fpass2,fpass3)) module(cgscc(cgpass1,cgpass2,cgpass3)) module(function(loop(lpass1,lpass2,lpass3)))

This shortcut is especially useful for debugging and testing small pass combinations.

The sequence of passes aren&#39;t necessarily the exact same kind of pass. You can mix different levels implicitly if adaptor passes are defined to make them work. For example,

mpass1,fpass1,fpass2,mpass2,lpass1

This pipeline uses only one pass manager: the top-level module manager. fpass1,fpass2 and lpass1 are added into the top-level module manager using only adaptor passes. No nested function/loop pass managers are added. The purpose is to allow easy pass testing when the user specifically want the pass to run under a adaptor directly. This is preferred when a pipeline is largely of one type, but one or just a few passes are of different types(See <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilder-cpp">PassBuilder.cpp</a> for examples).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00351">351</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilder-cpp/#l02247">2247</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/passes/passbuilder-cpp">PassBuilder.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Error PassBuilder::parsePassPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a4ded4558d2b58dcdd7a1736aa69a8bc4">CGSCCPassManager</a> &amp; CGPM, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> PipelineText)</>}>

function(lpass)

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> a callback for a default optimizer pipeline extension point.

This extension point allows adding late loop canonicalization and simplification passes. This is the last point in the loop optimization pipeline before loop deletion. Each pass added here must be an instance of <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/looppass">LoopPass</a>. This is the place to add passes that can remove loops, such as target- specific loop idiom recognition.

### parsePassParameters() {#ad552dcd2825d0f59fae310931b7813bb}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename ParametersParseCallableT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>static decltype(Parser(StringRef&#123;&#125;)) llvm::PassBuilder::parsePassParameters (ParametersParseCallableT &amp;&amp; Parser, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Name, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> PassName)</>}
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
This performs customized parsing of pass name with parameters.

We do not need parametrization of passes in textual pipeline very often, yet on a rare occasion ability to specify parameters right there can be useful.

<code>Name</code> - parameterized specification of a pass from a textual pipeline is a string in a form of : PassName &#39;&lt;&#39; parameter-list &#39;&gt;&#39;

Parameter list is being parsed by the parser callable argument, <code>Parser</code>, It takes a string-ref of parameters and returns either <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringerror">StringError</a> or a parameter list in a form of a custom parameters type, all wrapped into <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/expected">Expected&lt;&gt;</a> template class.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h/#l00675">675</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/passes/passbuilder-h">PassBuilder.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
